thread.title: Historic photos of Austin show it was cool to live there before it was cool to live there -
thread.title_full: Historic photos of Austin show it was cool to live there before it was cool to live there - Houston Chronicle

author: chron.com
title: Historic photos of Austin show it was cool to live there before it was cool to live there -

organizations.name: new york daily news archive/ny daily news via getty images
bob bullock texas state history museum

text:
Photo: Alfred Eisenstaedt/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images Image 1 of / 95 Caption
Close
Image 1 of 95 Historical photos of Austin before it became the best cities to live in .
U.S. News & World Report ranked the best American cities to live in and Austin landed on top, but these photos prove that Austin has always been an incredible city for generations. Continue clicking to see historic photos of Austin before it became the "best."
less Historical photos of Austin before it became the best cities to live in .
U.S. News & World Report ranked the best American cities to live in and Austin landed on top, but these photos prove that Austin has
... more Photo: Alfred Eisenstaedt/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images Image 2 of 95 Congress Street leads up to the capitol building in Austin and nothing has really changed much, except the skyscrapers, of course. This photo was taken around 1948.
Congress Street leads up to the capitol building in Austin and nothing has really changed much, except the skyscrapers, of course. This photo was taken around 1948.
Photo: PhotoQuest/Getty Images Image 3 of 95 Congress Street leads up to the capitol building in Austin and nothing has really changed much, except the skyscrapers, of course. This photo was taken around 1965.
Congress Street leads up to the capitol building in Austin and nothing has really changed much, except the skyscrapers, of course. This photo was taken around 1965.
Photo: Keystone-France/Gamma-Keystone Via Getty Images Image 4 of 95 Before there was Whole Foods on Lamar Blvd., there were local farmers markets with your friendly neighbors.
Before there was Whole Foods on Lamar Blvd., there were local farmers markets with your friendly neighbors.
Photo: Visual Studies Workshop/Getty Images Image 5 of 95 And tiny homes in Austin weren't an original idea. Here is a family traveling in their temporary tiny home to go work in the cotton fields.
And tiny homes in Austin weren't an original idea. Here is a family traveling in their temporary tiny home to go work in the cotton fields.
Photo: Buyenlarge/Getty Images Image 6 of 95 Hotel Driskill looks pretty much the same.
Hotel Driskill looks pretty much the same.
Photo: Francis Miller/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images Image 7 of 95 Football at the University of Texas was still a center point of the college campus. Check out all of those people in the stands. Not nearly as crowded as the Royal Stadium can get.
Football at the University of Texas was still a center point of the college campus. Check out all of those people in the stands. Not nearly as crowded as the Royal Stadium can get.
Photo: Francis Miller/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images Image 8 of 95 And for the private school sports, St. Edwards had their men's baseball team to cheer on. Those uniforms are a hipster's dream outfit.
And for the private school sports, St. Edwards had their men's baseball team to cheer on. Those uniforms are a hipster's dream outfit.
Photo: Transcendental Graphics/Getty Images Image 9 of 95 Church in Austin took a more natural approach.
Church in Austin took a more natural approach.
Photo: Underwood Archives/Getty Images Image 10 of 95 A preacher and his two white-robed assistants await converts from the shore for a baptism in the Colorado River, Austin, Texas, June 2, 1938.
A preacher and his two white-robed assistants await converts from the shore for a baptism in the Colorado River, Austin, Texas, June 2, 1938.
Photo: Underwood Archives/Getty Images Image 11 of 95 Females represent as Mirian Ferguson takes oath as Texas governor for the second time on January 19, 1933.
Females represent as Mirian Ferguson takes oath as Texas governor for the second time on January 19, 1933.
Photo: Keystone-France/Gamma-Keystone Via Getty Images Image 12 of 95 Sadly, being environmentally friendly wasn't always a priority of Austinites. The photo shows the factory complex of the National Tube Co., a subsidiary of US Steel, spewing out its toxic smoke from dozens of smokestacks.
less Sadly, being environmentally friendly wasn't always a priority of Austinites. The photo shows the factory complex of the National Tube Co., a subsidiary of US Steel, spewing out its toxic smoke from dozens of
... more Photo: Andreas Feininger/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images Image 13 of 95 And classic cowboying has also been a staple in Austin. The photo above is a University of Texas rodeo in Austin, which was attended by teams from 13 other Southwestern schools.
And classic cowboying has also been a staple in Austin. The photo above is a University of Texas rodeo in Austin, which was attended by teams from 13 other Southwestern schools.
Photo: Thomas D. McAvoy/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images Image 14 of 95 Calf-roping during the University of Texas rodeo in Austin, which is attended by teams from 13 other Southwestern schools.
Calf-roping during the University of Texas rodeo in Austin, which is attended by teams from 13 other Southwestern schools.
Photo: Thomas D. McAvoy/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images Image 15 of 95 Bull riding during the University of Texas rodeo in Austin, which is attended by teams from 13 other Southwestern schools.
Bull riding during the University of Texas rodeo in Austin, which is attended by teams from 13 other Southwestern schools.
Photo: Thomas D. McAvoy/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images Image 16 of 95 Bronc riding during the University of Texas rodeo in Austin, which is attended by teams from 13 other Southwestern schools.
Bronc riding during the University of Texas rodeo in Austin, which is attended by teams from 13 other Southwestern schools.
Photo: Thomas D. McAvoy/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images Image 17 of 95 Aerial view of the University of Texas campus around the 1960s.
Aerial view of the University of Texas campus around the 1960s.
Photo: Donald Uhrbrock/The LIFE Images Collection/Getty Images Image 18 of 95 Politics have always been a central focus of the Austin community. Above shows the victory celebration for Lyndon Johnson's election as president.
Politics have always been a central focus of the Austin community. Above shows the victory celebration for Lyndon Johnson's election as president.
Photo: John Dominis/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images Image 19 of 95 A view showing the exterior of the Capitol Building in Austin.
A view showing the exterior of the Capitol Building in Austin.
Photo: Carl Mydans/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images Image 20 of 95 American politicians US President Ronald Reagan (1911 - 2004) (center) and Vice President George HW Bush (center left) pose with cheerleaders during a stop on their reelection campaign, Austin, Texas, July 26, 1984.
less American politicians US President Ronald Reagan (1911 - 2004) (center) and Vice President George HW Bush (center left) pose with cheerleaders during a stop on their reelection campaign, Austin, Texas, July 26,
... more Photo: Robert R. McElroy/Getty Images Image 21 of 95 Supporters celebrate the victory of their candidate, democrat Lyndon Johnson, in the 1964 US Presidential Election, Austin, Texas November 3, 1964.
Supporters celebrate the victory of their candidate, democrat Lyndon Johnson, in the 1964 US Presidential Election, Austin, Texas November 3, 1964.
Photo: John Dominis/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images Image 22 of 95
Image 23 of 95 1913: A drug store delivery boy, twelve years old. San Antonio, Texas. 1913.This was also the years that "The Daily Texan" became the first daily college newspaper in the South.
1913: A drug store delivery boy, twelve years old. San Antonio, Texas. 1913.This was also the years that "The Daily Texan" became the first daily college newspaper in the South.
Photo: Universal History Archive/UIG Via Getty Images, Getty Images Image 24 of 95 1920: Farming is a big part of Texas culture. This year large-scale agricultural irrigation begins in the High Plains.
1920: Farming is a big part of Texas culture. This year large-scale agricultural irrigation begins in the High Plains.
Photo: Vintage Images/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 25 of 95 1936: The Texas Centennial Exposition was held at Dallas' Fair Park, which is now a historical landmark. This celebration marked 100 years of independence from Mexico and celebrated the Western American culture.
less 1936: The Texas Centennial Exposition was held at Dallas' Fair Park, which is now a historical landmark. This celebration marked 100 years of independence from Mexico and celebrated the Western American
... more Photo: PhotoQuest/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 26 of 95 1941: Married members of the University of Texas football team posing with their wives. All the while, World War II had just started and five Texas City plants become major production sites for critical materials causing a population boom.
less 1941: Married members of the University of Texas football team posing with their wives. All the while, World War II had just started and five Texas City plants become major production sites for critical
... more Photo: George Strock/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 27 of 95 1942: Boys playing marbles in a labour camp in Robstown, Texas. Around this time, an announcement was made that a place near Killeen, Texas would be established as a tank destroyer tactical and firing center.
1942: Boys playing marbles in a labour camp in Robstown, Texas. Around this time, an announcement was made that a place near Killeen, Texas would be established as a tank destroyer tactical and firing center.
Photo: Universal History Archive/UIG Via Getty Images, Getty Images Image 28 of 95 1950: The city of Houston began to grow. Not only did the Texas Medical Center become operational, but the Galveston Freeway and what is now Hobby Airport started to become a major source of increasing wealth.
1950: The city of Houston began to grow. Not only did the Texas Medical Center become operational, but the Galveston Freeway and what is now Hobby Airport started to become a major source of increasing wealth.
Photo: Joseph Scherschel/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 29 of 95 1951: Aerial view of smoke coming from chimneys on the roof of the Champion Paper Co. The paper company set up shop in Houston hoping to take advantage of the cheap pine, but the paper industry was slow. The company saw decline, which eventually led to it being bought out.
less 1951: Aerial view of smoke coming from chimneys on the roof of the Champion Paper Co. The paper company set up shop in Houston hoping to take advantage of the cheap pine, but the paper industry was slow. The
... more Photo: Margaret Bourke-White/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 30 of 95 1952: The City Of Kilgore, Texas represents the geographical heart of oilfields in Eastern Texas, better known as the World Oil City. This was also the year that the first leg of the Gulf Freeway connecting Houston and Galveston was dedicated.
less 1952: The City Of Kilgore, Texas represents the geographical heart of oilfields in Eastern Texas, better known as the World Oil City. This was also the year that the first leg of the Gulf Freeway connecting
... more Photo: Keystone-France/Gamma-Keystone Via Getty Images, Getty Images Image 31 of 95 1953: A woman being saved from the wreckage of an F5 tornado that happened in Waco during the Waco tornado outbreak sequence. This was the most severe of all the tornadoes. Over 100 people lost their lives making it the deadliest tornado in Texas history.
less 1953: A woman being saved from the wreckage of an F5 tornado that happened in Waco during the Waco tornado outbreak sequence. This was the most severe of all the tornadoes. Over 100 people lost their lives
... more Photo: John Dominis/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 32 of 95 1954: Little girl swinging about flood waters in the Rio Grande Valley. Women in Texas gained a huge victory this year by earning the right to serve on juries.
1954: Little girl swinging about flood waters in the Rio Grande Valley. Women in Texas gained a huge victory this year by earning the right to serve on juries.
Photo: John Dominis/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 33 of 95 1955: White-faced Herefords being shown at San Antonio stock show by Four-H teenagers. The King himself, Elvis Presley rocked Texas this year with at least 100 stops from big cities to high school auditoriums to baseball fields.
less 1955: White-faced Herefords being shown at San Antonio stock show by Four-H teenagers. The King himself, Elvis Presley rocked Texas this year with at least 100 stops from big cities to high school auditoriums
... more Photo: Joseph Scherschel/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 34 of 95 1956: A new monorail service in Houston, Texas, ready for its inaugural service. The concept, however interesting and innovative, was dismantled later the same year.
1956: A new monorail service in Houston, Texas, ready for its inaugural service. The concept, however interesting and innovative, was dismantled later the same year.
Photo: Evans/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 35 of 95 1957: Ernest Tubb and His Texas Troubadours at the Ernest Tubb Record Shop. Good thing these men we're in Galveston gambling, because they may have gotten caught up in the raid that ultimately shut down gambling and other illegals businesses on the island.
less 1957: Ernest Tubb and His Texas Troubadours at the Ernest Tubb Record Shop. Good thing these men we're in Galveston gambling, because they may have gotten caught up in the raid that ultimately shut down
... more Photo: Elmer Williams/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 36 of 95 1958: Unidentified twin brothers appearing on "Midnite Jamboree" with Ernest Tubb, his Texas Troubadours, and one of the Wilburn Brothers. Meanwhile, all the way in Moscow, Louisianan-born, but Texas-raised pianist Van Cliburn was busy winning the International Tchaikovsky Piano Competition and earning worldwide recognition.
less 1958: Unidentified twin brothers appearing on "Midnite Jamboree" with Ernest Tubb, his Texas Troubadours, and one of the Wilburn Brothers. Meanwhile, all the way in Moscow, Louisianan-born, but Texas-raised
... more Photo: Elmer Williams/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 37 of 95 1959: The Houston ship channel was beginning showing rapid growth. While many positive things were happening, Texas lost the great Buddy Holly this year.
1959: The Houston ship channel was beginning showing rapid growth. While many positive things were happening, Texas lost the great Buddy Holly this year.
Photo: Getty Images Image 38 of 95 1960: A young woman updates stock prices at a brokerage firm in Dallas, Texas. This was also the year that the Dallas Cowboys were born.
1960: A young woman updates stock prices at a brokerage firm in Dallas, Texas. This was also the year that the Dallas Cowboys were born.
Photo: Shel Hershorn - HA/Inactive/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 39 of 95 1961: A view of the wreckage after Hurricane Carla. The storm was a category 5 hurricane, the most intense hurricane to make landfall in Texas.
1961: A view of the wreckage after Hurricane Carla. The storm was a category 5 hurricane, the most intense hurricane to make landfall in Texas.
Photo: Grey Villet/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 40 of 95 1962: Nasa's Mission Control room, Houston, Texas in operation during the second day of the Gemini V spaceflight. The spacecraft carried two astronauts and lasted until 1966.
1962: Nasa's Mission Control room, Houston, Texas in operation during the second day of the Gemini V spaceflight. The spacecraft carried two astronauts and lasted until 1966.
Photo: Evans/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 41 of 95 1963: Photographers running shortly after assassination of John F. Kennedy at 12:30 p.m. in Dallas.
1963: Photographers running shortly after assassination of John F. Kennedy at 12:30 p.m. in Dallas.
Photo: Art Rickerby/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 42 of 95 1964: Encephalitis ward at Ben Taub hospital during an epidemic. The disease can be fatal and is transmitted by mosquitoes. During the summer of 1964 over 100 people were admitted into the hospital with signs of brain infection.
less 1964: Encephalitis ward at Ben Taub hospital during an epidemic. The disease can be fatal and is transmitted by mosquitoes. During the summer of 1964 over 100 people were admitted into the hospital with signs
... more Photo: Donald Uhrbrock/The LIFE Images Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 43 of 95 1965: A group, including astronaut Frank Borman's wife cheering as his shuttle returns from a 14-day spacefight as part of the Gemini project started in 1962. Borman was also the Captain aboard Apollo 8.
1965: A group, including astronaut Frank Borman's wife cheering as his shuttle returns from a 14-day spacefight as part of the Gemini project started in 1962. Borman was also the Captain aboard Apollo 8.
Photo: Donald Uhrbrock/The LIFE Images Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 44 of 95 1966: Mrs. Neil Armstrong at home after husband's Gemini 8 mission was cut short because of problems that forced them to make a emergency landing in the Pacific. This was the first in-space system failure that seriously endangered the lives of the crew.
less 1966: Mrs. Neil Armstrong at home after husband's Gemini 8 mission was cut short because of problems that forced them to make a emergency landing in the Pacific. This was the first in-space system failure that
... more Photo: Ralph Morse/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 45 of 95 1967: Homes flooded by hurricane Beulah, which was only the second storm, and only major storm, of the 1967 hurricane season. It made landfall as a category 3 storm and spawned over 100 tornadoes across Texas, establishing a new record for number of tornadoes produces by a tropical cyclone.
less 1967: Homes flooded by hurricane Beulah, which was only the second storm, and only major storm, of the 1967 hurricane season. It made landfall as a category 3 storm and spawned over 100 tornadoes across Texas,
... more Photo: Donald Uhrbrock/The LIFE Images Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 46 of 95 1968: American politician and real estate developer, former Houston Mayor Roy Hofheinz poses with his grandchildren in a private room at the Astrodome in Houston. Behind him is a puppet stage labelled "Astrotots Theatre," which was only a small part of his gaudy apartment in the Astrodome.
less 1968: American politician and real estate developer, former Houston Mayor Roy Hofheinz poses with his grandchildren in a private room at the Astrodome in Houston. Behind him is a puppet stage labelled
... more Photo: Mark Kauffman/Time & Life Pictures/Getty Image, Getty Images Image 47 of 95 1969: American astronaut Edwin E. Aldrin Jr (also known as Buzz) and his son on an amusement park ride, Texas, 1969. Buzz Aldrin was among the first to land on the moon along with Neil Armstrong also in 1969.
1969: American astronaut Edwin E. Aldrin Jr (also known as Buzz) and his son on an amusement park ride, Texas, 1969. Buzz Aldrin was among the first to land on the moon along with Neil Armstrong also in 1969.
Photo: Lee Balterman/The LIFE Images Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 48 of 95 1970: The Apollo 13 astronauts and their wives gather at Mission Commander Jim Lovell's house for a party, Houston. Apollo 13 launched on April 11. A lunar landing was planned, but had to be aborted after the oxygen tank exploded. The crew faced many difficulties, but returned to earth on April 17.
less 1970: The Apollo 13 astronauts and their wives gather at Mission Commander Jim Lovell's house for a party, Houston. Apollo 13 launched on April 11. A lunar landing was planned, but had to be aborted after the
... more Photo: Ralph Morse/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 49 of 95 1971: A view of the Mission Operations Control Room in Houston minutes after the launch of the Apollo 15 lunar landing mission, 26th July 1971. This was the first mission where a Lunar Roving Vehicle was used to explore the moon.
less 1971: A view of the Mission Operations Control Room in Houston minutes after the launch of the Apollo 15 lunar landing mission, 26th July 1971. This was the first mission where a Lunar Roving Vehicle was used
... more Photo: Print Collector/Print Collector/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 50 of 95 1972: House speaker Gus Mutscher and two associates were convicted for conspiracy and bribery in the Sharpstown Scandal. The stock fraud scandal involved several members in the highest level of state government.
less 1972: House speaker Gus Mutscher and two associates were convicted for conspiracy and bribery in the Sharpstown Scandal. The stock fraud scandal involved several members in the highest level of state
... more Photo: Vernon Merritt III/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 51 of 95 1973: Driver Bobby Allison holds up a confederate flag with Miss Winston, Noneen Hulbert, before the Alamo 500 race at the Texas World Speedway in College Station. This was also the year that Texas' most historic brothel, the Chicken Ranch at La Grange officially closed.
less 1973: Driver Bobby Allison holds up a confederate flag with Miss Winston, Noneen Hulbert, before the Alamo 500 race at the Texas World Speedway in College Station. This was also the year that Texas' most
... more Photo: Dozier Mobley/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 52 of 95 1974: The rock band Deep Purple played at the Astrodome in Houston on 30th August 1974. The group was introducing a new lineup after a couple band members quit the year before.
1974: The rock band Deep Purple played at the Astrodome in Houston on 30th August 1974. The group was introducing a new lineup after a couple band members quit the year before.
Photo: Fin Costello/Redferns, Getty Images Image 53 of 95 1975: American artist Alexander Calder paints the fuselage of a passenger plane as a commission from Braniff International Airways in Dallas. Initially Calder refused thinking he was being asked to paint a toy, but promptly accepted after being told it was a full-sized aircraft that would be seen as a "flying canvas."
less 1975: American artist Alexander Calder paints the fuselage of a passenger plane as a commission from Braniff International Airways in Dallas. Initially Calder refused thinking he was being asked to paint a toy,
... more Photo: Camerique/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 54 of 95 1976: Two tourists from Ft. Worth, Texas feed the ducks and geese in City Park. This was also the year that an ammonia truck fell off a freeway spilling over 7,000 gallons of lethal chemicals.
1976: Two tourists from Ft. Worth, Texas feed the ducks and geese in City Park. This was also the year that an ammonia truck fell off a freeway spilling over 7,000 gallons of lethal chemicals.
Photo: Kenn Bisio/Denver Post Via Getty Images, Getty Images Image 55 of 95 1977: A fisherman lands largemouth bass from swivel seat in boat. Miss Texas also took the title of Miss USA this year, and went on to compete for the title of Miss Universe, which was taken by Miss Trinidad & Tobago.
less 1977: A fisherman lands largemouth bass from swivel seat in boat. Miss Texas also took the title of Miss USA this year, and went on to compete for the title of Miss Universe, which was taken by Miss Trinidad &
... more Photo: Bob Saile/Denver Post Via Getty Images, Getty Images Image 56 of 95 1978: Ron Galella backstage at a Leif Garrett concert Houston, Texas. This was the year Garrett's self-titled debut album was released. Texas Instruments patented the first speech synthesis chip, which electronically replicated the human voice and led to products like Speak & Spell.
less 1978: Ron Galella backstage at a Leif Garrett concert Houston, Texas. This was the year Garrett's self-titled debut album was released. Texas Instruments patented the first speech synthesis chip, which
... more Photo: Brad Elterman/BuzzFoto/FilmMagic, Getty Images Image 57 of 95 1979: Interior of Shuttle Cockpit Simulator used for training astronauts for space flight, at Johnson Space Center. Meanwhile, someone bought a pig for $42,500, the largest amount ever paid for a pig.
1979: Interior of Shuttle Cockpit Simulator used for training astronauts for space flight, at Johnson Space Center. Meanwhile, someone bought a pig for $42,500, the largest amount ever paid for a pig.
Photo: Time Life Pictures/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 58 of 95 1980: Dr. Kenneth H. Cooper, widely recognized as the founder of the physical fitness movement conducts a treadmill test at the Cooper Aerobics Center in Dallas. However, people probably didn't want to work out given the intense heat wave that was sweeping across the nation. Temperatures in Dallas exceed 100 °F for 42 consecutive days this year, with the all-time high being 113 for three consecutive days.
less 1980: Dr. Kenneth H. Cooper, widely recognized as the founder of the physical fitness movement conducts a treadmill test at the Cooper Aerobics Center in Dallas. However, people probably didn't want to work
... more Photo: David Madison/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 59 of 95 1981: A view of Johnson Space Center, Mission control as the first manned Shuttle, Columbia, crewed by Robert Crippen and John Young, made its landing. Columbia orbited 36 times before landing safely back on Earth. The Space Shuttle was the world's first partially reusable launch vehicle.
less 1981: A view of Johnson Space Center, Mission control as the first manned Shuttle, Columbia, crewed by Robert Crippen and John Young, made its landing. Columbia orbited 36 times before landing safely back on
... more Photo: Getty Images Image 60 of 95 1982: Charles Brooks Jr. became the first person to be executed by lethal injection.
1982: Charles Brooks Jr. became the first person to be executed by lethal injection.
Photo: Getty Images Image 61 of 95 1983: San Antonio had the river walk, but Houston had Nolan Ryan. The Astro struck out his 3,500 batter this year.
1983: San Antonio had the river walk, but Houston had Nolan Ryan. The Astro struck out his 3,500 batter this year.
Photo: Gianni Ferrari/Cover/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 62 of 95 1984: Female police officers restrain radical Gregory Johnson after his flag-burning demonstration to express anger against Reagan policies during the Republican National Convention, which was held in Dallas.
1984: Female police officers restrain radical Gregory Johnson after his flag-burning demonstration to express anger against Reagan policies during the Republican National Convention, which was held in Dallas.
Photo: David Leeson/Image Works/The LIFE Images Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 63 of 95 1985: Workers in a suburb of Dallas, laying beams on the ground with house under construction in the rear. Texas savings-and-loan companies applying for state charters get their deposit insurance suspended by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
less 1985: Workers in a suburb of Dallas, laying beams on the ground with house under construction in the rear. Texas savings-and-loan companies applying for state charters get their deposit insurance suspended by
... more Photo: Shelly Katz/The LIFE Images Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 64 of 95 1986: Tearful Nancy Reagan cuddling Joy McNair, baby daughter of astronaut Ronald McNair who died along with six others in fatal explosion on the space shuttle Challenger in January 1986. This resulted in a 32-month hiatus for the shuttle space program.
less 1986: Tearful Nancy Reagan cuddling Joy McNair, baby daughter of astronaut Ronald McNair who died along with six others in fatal explosion on the space shuttle Challenger in January 1986. This resulted in a
... more Photo: Diana Walker/Time & Life Pictures/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 65 of 95 1987: Astronauts test a Crew Escape System (CES) design on March 20, 1987 at Johnson Space Center in Houston, Texas. After the 1986 explosion of the Space Shuttle Challenger, NASA set about designing escape systems for space shuttle crews.
less 1987: Astronauts test a Crew Escape System (CES) design on March 20, 1987 at Johnson Space Center in Houston, Texas. After the 1986 explosion of the Space Shuttle Challenger, NASA set about designing escape
... more Photo: Getty Images Image 66 of 95 1988: The 66 Courts Motel on Historic Route 66 as it passes through Groom, Texas, 1988. (Photo by Richard Jordan/Hulton Archive/Getty Images)
1988: The 66 Courts Motel on Historic Route 66 as it passes through Groom, Texas, 1988. (Photo by Richard Jordan/Hulton Archive/Getty Images)
Photo: Richard Jordan/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 67 of 95 1989: An unidentified pole vaulter clears the bar during the TAC Championships in Houston, Texas. Miss Texas, Gretchen Polhemus, was crowed Miss USA this year.
1989: An unidentified pole vaulter clears the bar during the TAC Championships in Houston, Texas. Miss Texas, Gretchen Polhemus, was crowed Miss USA this year.
Photo: Tim DeFrisco/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 68 of 95 1990: The Houston Astros during a game at the Astrodome. This was also the years that Ann Richards (D) became the first female governor of Texas.
1990: The Houston Astros during a game at the Astrodome. This was also the years that Ann Richards (D) became the first female governor of Texas.
Photo: Focus On Sport/Focus On Sport/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 69 of 95 1992: Volunteers pick Lenoir grapes at Messina Hof Vineyards August 6, 1992 in Bryan, TX. This was also the year the Texas Lottery was launched. Governor Ann Richardson bought the first ticket in the summer, and the first drawing was held in November.
less 1992: Volunteers pick Lenoir grapes at Messina Hof Vineyards August 6, 1992 in Bryan, TX. This was also the year the Texas Lottery was launched. Governor Ann Richardson bought the first ticket in the summer,
... more Photo: Paul S. Howell/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 70 of 95 1993: NASA astronaut Ellen Ochoa during training at Vance Air Force base in Houston. In Waco, federal agents raided the Branch Davidians cult compound. They were believed to have a large arsenal of assault weapons.
less 1993: NASA astronaut Ellen Ochoa during training at Vance Air Force base in Houston. In Waco, federal agents raided the Branch Davidians cult compound. They were believed to have a large arsenal of assault
... more Photo: NASA/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 71 of 95 1994: Kim Fowley holds court at the South by Southwest Music Festival in March 1994 in Austin. This was the first year the music festival used film and other media as part of the event.
1994: Kim Fowley holds court at the South by Southwest Music Festival in March 1994 in Austin. This was the first year the music festival used film and other media as part of the event.
Photo: Catherine McGann/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 72 of 95 1995: The River Walk's Hard Rock Cafe, and other well-known places opened this year. This was also the year that Selena was killed in Corpus Christi.
1995: The River Walk's Hard Rock Cafe, and other well-known places opened this year. This was also the year that Selena was killed in Corpus Christi.
Photo: Wolfgang Kaehler/LightRocket Via Getty Images, Getty Images Image 73 of 95 1996: Texas faced scorching heat as a severe drought brought the most agricultural loses ever seen in a one-year drought.
1996: Texas faced scorching heat as a severe drought brought the most agricultural loses ever seen in a one-year drought.
Photo: Shelly Katz/The LIFE Images Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 74 of 95 1997: Marshall Herff Applewhite, the chairman of the music department at the University of St. Thomas and the Heaven's Gate apocalyptic Christian cult leader, led 38 people to their death in a mass suicide.
1997: Marshall Herff Applewhite, the chairman of the music department at the University of St. Thomas and the Heaven's Gate apocalyptic Christian cult leader, led 38 people to their death in a mass suicide.
Photo: Mark Perlstein/The LIFE Images Collection/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 75 of 95 1998: Researchers in Dallas unveil their findings about an enzyme that can help slow apoptosis, or cell death, which in turn slows the aging process.
1998: Researchers in Dallas unveil their findings about an enzyme that can help slow apoptosis, or cell death, which in turn slows the aging process.
Photo: Visions Of America/UIG Via Getty Images, Getty Images Image 76 of 95 1999: Twelve members of the Aggie family were killed in a bonfire collapse, causing the university to end one of its longest held and most beloved traditions. The tragedy's impact still lingers today. 1999: Twelve members of the Aggie family were killed in a bonfire collapse, causing the university to end one of its longest held and most beloved traditions. The tragedy's impact still lingers today. Photo: DOUG SEHRES, AP Image 77 of 95 2000: Former Texas governor, George W. Bush is elected president after the Supreme Court released it's decision in Bush v. Gore.
2000: Former Texas governor, George W. Bush is elected president after the Supreme Court released it's decision in Bush v. Gore.
Photo: Getty Images Image 78 of 95 2001: The 1940 theater neon sign from Sherman, Texas anchors the Texas Spirit Theater at the new Bob Bullock Texas State History Museum that opened this year in Austin. 2001: The 1940 theater neon sign from Sherman, Texas anchors the Texas Spirit Theater at the new Bob Bullock Texas State History Museum that opened this year in Austin. Photo: E. Joseph Deering, Houston Chronicle Image 79 of 95 2002 : Andrew Fastow, chief financial officer of Enron Corp. is indicted on 78 counts of wire fraud, money laundering, conspiracy and obstruction of justice in relation to the fall of the company.
2002 : Andrew Fastow, chief financial officer of Enron Corp. is indicted on 78 counts of wire fraud, money laundering, conspiracy and obstruction of justice in relation to the fall of the company.
Photo: James Nielsen/Getty Images, Getty Images Image 80 of 95 2003: Space Shuttle Columbia broke up during reentry killing the sever crew members aboard. T he Crew Escape Systems that were in place on the Space Shuttle Columbia could not have saved the crew.
2003: Space Shuttle Columbia broke up during reentry killing the sever crew members aboard. T he Crew Escape Systems that were in place on the Space Shuttle Columbia could not have saved the crew.
Image 81 of 95 2004: The infamous Janet Jackson wardrobe malfunction during the halftime show for Super Bowl 38 happened in Houston.

... more Photo: Buyenlarge/Getty Images Image 95 of 95 Historic photos of Austin show it was cool to live there before it was cool to live there 1 / 95 Back to Gallery Earlier in February, the U.S. News & World Report named Austin as the best American city to live in for 2017. But photos of Austin decades ago prove that the best city in America has always been pretty great.
The Houston neighbor may not be as diverse as the Bayou City, but its history runs just as deep within Texas. The village of Waterloo was established in 1837 and has grown into what modern Americans know as Austin.
FULL REPORT: Austin lands in top 25 of 2017 U.S. News & World Report's Best Places to Live list
The cities with the greatest potential for growth in 2017 may not necessarily have famed skylines.
Media: ELLE Decor Quickly after settling, Waterloo changed its name to Austin and in 1839 the city became the capital of Texas (which was formally Houston - no hard feelings or anything). The name Austin was chosen to honor Stephen F. Austin, who was considered the "Father of Texas" and the republic's first secretary of state.
Photos of these early times don't exist, but there are quite a few from 1900 and beyond. These photos show what Texans have already known all along - Austin is weird but great. From booming economies to extensive political involvement, the Austin of the past looks fairly similar to the Austin of the present. Click through the gallery above to see historic photos of Texas' capital city.
